subject: Languages
title: The Great Vowel Shift: English Gets Weird
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The Great Vowel Shift: English Gets Weird.

hook.text: Between 1400 and 1700, every long vowel in English shifted position. Nobody planned it. Nobody knows why.

buildup.text: Before the shift, 'bite' rhymed with 'meet,' 'house' sounded like 'hoose,' and 'name' rhymed with 'comma.'

discovery.text: Each vowel pushed the next one in a chain reaction â€” like linguistic dominoes falling over three centuries.

twist.text: English spelling was standardized during the shift â€” which is why spelling and pronunciation don't match today.

climax.text: The Great Vowel Shift is the main reason English spelling is so notoriously difficult.

punchline.text: English sounds changed for 300 years. The spelling froze. We're still confused.

quiz.question: What caused English spelling to mismatch its pronunciation?
options: Spelling was fixed during the Great Vowel Shift while sounds kept changing
English borrowed too many French words
The printing press used wrong letters
